column4: hey guys, is it possible to get installation packages not directly using Ubuntu?
i mean can i download that packages and install them on other computer which is not connected to internet?
i couldn't find that packages on ubuntu's offsite
could anyone help me with this?
yes, hold on i will get you a url
http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/
thank you very much
basically you can open your /etc/apt/sources.list file and go to any of the official repos and follow the "pool" links

the problem is that the computer running on Ubuntu is temporary not connected to Internet (for some reasons) but i want some software to install, that's why i'd like to get those packages and install them later
ok, visit that url on a box that has a connection, download what you want, burn to cd, take it to the other box and install.. but you may have a problem with deps
unless you already know which deps you need and dl those too
anyways, i'm downloading them, and I'll try to install them as you've stated. Hope won't be any problems
i used that method on a box without a conn, but u had to go back and forth due to the various deps. some apps have a lot of deps.. some dont have many

one more thing, I don't really understand the differences between different Linux versions but i got only Ubuntu installation CD, what do you think - is it a good choice? or it will be pain to use for a newbie like me?
i have been through several distros, including fedora debian archlinux centos mepis, and i feel that ubuntu is the downright best distro available. its easy to use and easy to learn.
im a newbie too and ubuntu roxors!
can i install apache/mysql stuff and use on network like a server with Ubuntu desktop or should i install Server version?
i have LAMP (Linux Apache MySQL Php) installed on my desktop pc and i love it.
i tried LAMP but got some problems that i couldn't solve with vhosts
well, youre in a good channel to get that solved. also have a look at ubuntuforums.org  that is one nice forum
thanx, i'll be here then for a while =)
the as LAMP but for Windows
